natural problem: Euclid, Pythagoras, Ptolemy, and Hypatia are playing a game where they all have to think of a number, and then cube that number 20 times. Hypatia doesn't want to cube large numbers, so she chooses the number 1. Euclid thinks the same thing and also chooses the number 1. However, Pythagoras and Ptolemy don't think ahead and Pythagoras chooses 2 and Ptolemy chooses -2. After they finish cubing their numbers (Pythagoras and Ptolemy take a while), all four players write their final numbers on a piece of paper. What is the sum of the numbers they wrote on the piece of paper?
natural solution: The number 1 to any power is always 1, so no matter how many times Hypatia and Euclid cube their numbers, they will both always have the number 1.
Thus, Hypatia and Euclid both write down the number 1.

Now, lets take a look at Pythagoras. He keeps cubing his result 20 times starting with the number 2. The numbers he has are \begin{align} 2^3&\underset{\swarrow}{=}8 \\ 8^3&\underset{\swarrow}{=}512 \\

512^3&\underset{\swarrow}{=}134217728 \\ \vdots \end{align}We can see that these numbers get out of hand pretty quickly (no wonder it took them so long), so instead, we look at the sum of the results because that is what we are trying to find.
Recall that $(-a)^3=-a^3$. Because the number Ptolemy chose is the negation of what Pythagoras chose, after a certain number of cubes, whatever Pythagoras has, Ptolemy will have the opposite of that.
Thus, whatever gigantic number Pythagoras has at the end of the game, Ptolemy will have the negation of that number, and they will add to zero.
Thus, our desired sum is  \begin{align}1+1&+(\text{some huge number}) + (-\text{the same huge number})\\ &=1+1+0=\boxed{2}. \end{align}

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes Hypatia Euclid Pythagoras Ptolemy :: int
assumes h0 : "Hypatia = 1 ^ 60"
and h1 : "Euclid = 1 ^ 60"
and h2 : "Pythagoras = 2 ^ 60"
and h3 : "Ptolemy = (-2) ^ 60"
shows  "Hypatia + Euclid + Pythagoras + Ptolemy = 2"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Euclid, Pythagoras, Ptolemy, and Hypatia are playing a game where they all have to think of a number, and then cube that number 20 times. Hypatia doesn't want to cube large numbers, so she chooses the number 1. Euclid thinks the same thing and also chooses the number 1. However, Pythagoras and Ptolemy don't think ahead and Pythagoras chooses 2 and Ptolemy chooses -2. After they finish cubing their numbers (Pythagoras and Ptolemy take a while), all four players write their final numbers on a piece of paper. What is the sum of the numbers they wrote on the piece of paper? The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 The number 1 to any power is always 1, so no matter how many times Hypatia and Euclid cube their numbers, they will both always have the number 1.
 Thus, Hypatia and Euclid both write down the number 1.
 Now, lets take a look at Pythagoras. He keeps cubing his result 20 times starting with the number 2. The numbers he has are \begin{align} 2^3&\underset{\swarrow}{=}8 \\ 8^3&\underset{\swarrow}{=}512 \\
 512^3&\underset{\swarrow}{=}134217728 \\ \vdots \end{align}We can see that these numbers get out of hand pretty quickly (no wonder it took them so long), so instead, we look at the sum of the results because that is what we are trying to find.
 Recall that $(-a)^3=-a^3$. Because the number Ptolemy chose is the negation of what Pythagoras chose, after a certain number of cubes, whatever Pythagoras has, Ptolemy will have the opposite of that.
 Thus, whatever gigantic number Pythagoras has at the end of the game, Ptolemy will have the negation of that number, and they will add to zero.
 Thus, our desired sum is  \begin{align}1+1&+(\text{some huge number}) + (-\text{the same huge number})\\ &=1+1+0=\boxed{2}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes Hypatia Euclid Pythagoras Ptolemy :: int
assumes h0 : "Hypatia = 1 ^ 60"
and h1 : "Euclid = 1 ^ 60"
and h2 : "Pythagoras = 2 ^ 60"
and h3 : "Ptolemy = (-2) ^ 60"
shows  "Hypatia + Euclid + Pythagoras + Ptolemy = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Let Hypatia, Euclid, Pythagoras, and Ptolemy represent the values of $1^{60}$, $1^{60}$, $2^{60}$, and $(-2)^{60}$, respectively. What is the sum of these four values? The final answer is $2$.

fixes hypatia euclid pythagoras ptolemy :: real
assumes h0 : "hypatia = 1 powr 60"
and h1 : "euclid = 1 powr 60"
and h2 : "pythagoras = 2 powr 60"
and h3 : "ptolemy = ((-2) powr 60)"
shows  "hypatia + euclid + pythagoras + ptolemy = 2"
 proof-

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x y z w :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 1 powr 60"
and h1 : "y = 1 powr 60"
and h2 : "z = 2 powr 60"
and h3 : "w = (-2) powr 60"
shows  "x + y + z + w = 2"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 Thus, whatever gigantic number Pythagoras has at the end of the game, Ptolemy will have the negation of that number, and they will add to zero.
 Thus, our desired sum is  \begin{align}1+1&+(\text{some huge number}) + (-\text{the same huge number})\\ &=1+1+0=\boxed{2}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes x y z w :: real
assumes h0 : "x = 1 powr 60"
and h1 : "y = 1 powr 60"
and h2 : "z = 2 powr 60"
and h3 : "w = (-2) powr 60"
shows  "x + y + z + w = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Given that $x = 1^{60}$, $y = 1^{60}$, $z = 2^{60}$, and $w = (-2)^{60}$, find the sum of $x$, $y$, $z$, and $w$. The final answer is $2$.

fixes Hypatia Euclid Pythagoras Ptolemy :: real
assumes h0 : "Hypatia = 1 powr 60"

and h3 : "Ptolemy = (-2) powr 60"
shows  "Hypatia + Euclid + Pythagoras + Ptolemy = 2"

shows  "Hypatia + Euclid + Pythagoras + Ptolemy = 2"

(* ### Problem

theorem
fixes Hypatia Euclid Pythagoras Ptolemy :: real
assumes h0 : "Hypatia = 1^3^20"
and h1 : "Euclid = 1^3^20"
and h2 : "Pythagoras = 2^3^20"
and h3 : "Ptolemy = (-2)^3^20"
shows  "Hypatia + Euclid + Pythagoras + Ptolemy = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: "Calculate the sum of the following four values: Hypatia is the cube of 1 raised to the 20th power, Euclid is also the cube of 1 raised to the 20th power, Pythagoras is the cube of 2 raised to the 20th power, and Ptolemy is the cube of negative 2 raised to the 20th power. The final answer is 2."

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes Euclid Pythagoras Ptolemy Hypatia :: real
assumes h0 : "Euclid = 1"
and h1 : "Pythagoras = 2"
and h2 : "Ptolemy = -2"
and h3 : "Hypatia = 1"
and h4 : "\<forall> x. x = (x * x * x) ^ 20"
shows  "Euclid + Pythagoras + Ptolemy + Hypatia = 2"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Euclid, Pythagoras, Ptolemy, and Hypatia are playing a game where they all have to think of a number, and then cube that number 20 times. Hypatia doesn't want to cube large numbers, so she chooses the number 1. Euclid thinks the same thing and also chooses the number 1. However, Pythagoras and Ptolemy don't think ahead and Pythagoras chooses 2 and Ptolemy chooses -2. After they finish cubing their numbers (Pythagoras and Ptolemy take a while), all four players write their final numbers on a piece of paper. What is the sum of the numbers they wrote on the piece of paper? The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 The number 1 to any power is always 1, so no matter how many times Hypatia and Euclid cube their numbers, they will both always have the number 1.
 Thus, Hypatia and Euclid both write down the number 1.
 Now, lets take a look at Pythagoras. He keeps cubing his result 20 times starting with the number 2. The numbers he has are \begin{align} 2^3&\underset{\swarrow}{=}8 \\ 8^3&\underset{\swarrow}{=}512 \\

 Recall that $(-a)^3=-a^3$. Because the number Ptolemy chose is the negation of what Pythagoras chose, after a certain number of cubes, whatever Pythagoras has, Ptolemy will have the opposite of that.
 Thus, whatever gigantic number Pythagoras has at the end of the game, Ptolemy will have the negation of that number, and they will add to zero.
 Thus, our desired sum is  \begin{align}1+1&+(\text{some huge number}) + (-\text{the same huge number})\\ &=1+1+0=\boxed{2}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes Euclid Pythagoras Ptolemy Hypatia :: real
assumes h0 : "Euclid = 1"
and h1 : "Pythagoras = 2"
and h2 : "Ptolemy = -2"
and h3 : "Hypatia = 1"
and h4 : "\<forall> x. x = (x * x * x) ^ 20"
shows  "Euclid + Pythagoras + Ptolemy + Hypatia = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Suppose we have four real numbers, Euclid, Pythagoras, Ptolemy, and Hypatia, such that Euclid = 1, Pythagoras = 2, Ptolemy = -2, and Hypatia = 1. Furthermore, suppose that for any real number x, the value of x is equal to the twentieth power of the cube of x. Find the value of the sum of Euclid, Pythagoras, Ptolemy, and Hypatia. The final answer is 2.

 Now, lets take a look at Pythagoras. He keeps cubing his result 20 times starting with the number 2. The numbers he has are \begin{align} 2^3&\underset{\swarrow}{=}8 \\ 8^3&\underset{\swarrow}{=}512 \\
 512^3&\underset{\swarrow}{=}134217728 \\ \vdots \end{align}We can see that these numbers get out of hand pretty quickly (no wonder it took them so long), so instead, we look at the sum of the results because that is what we are trying to find.
 Recall that $(-a)^3=-a^3$. Because the number Ptolemy chose is the negation of what Pythagoras chose, after a certain number of cubes, whatever Pythagoras has, Ptolemy will have the opposite of that.
 Thus, whatever gigantic number Pythagoras has at the end of the game, Ptolemy will have the negation of that number, and they will add to zero.
 Thus, our desired sum is  \begin{align}1+1&+(\text{some huge number}) + (-\text{the same huge number})\\ &=1+1+0=\boxed{2}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes hypatia euclid pythagoras ptolemy :: int
assumes h0 : "hypatia = 1 powr 60"
and h1 : "euclid = 1 powr 60"
and h2 : "pythagoras = 2 powr 60"
and h3 : "ptolemy = -2 powr 60"
shows  "hypatia + euclid + pythagoras + ptolemy = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Let Hypatia, Euclid, Pythagoras and Ptolemy represent numbers such that Hypatia and Euclid are equal to 1 raised to the power of 60, Pythagoras is equal to 2 raised to the power of 60, and Ptolemy is equal to -2 raised to the power of 60. What is the sum of Hypatia, Euclid, Pythagoras and Ptolemy? The final answer is 2.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n1 n2 n3 n4 :: real
assumes h0 : "n1 = 1 ^ (3 ^ 20)"
and h1 : "n2 = 1 ^ (3 ^ 20)"
and h2 : "n3 = 2 ^ (3 ^ 20)"
and h3 : "n4 = (-2) ^ (3 ^ 20)"
shows  "n1 + n2 + n3 + n4 = 2"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Euclid, Pythagoras, Ptolemy, and Hypatia are playing a game where they all have to think of a number, and then cube that number 20 times. Hypatia doesn't want to cube large numbers, so she chooses the number 1. Euclid thinks the same thing and also chooses the number 1. However, Pythagoras and Ptolemy don't think ahead and Pythagoras chooses 2 and Ptolemy chooses -2. After they finish cubing their numbers (Pythagoras and Ptolemy take a while), all four players write their final numbers on a piece of paper. What is the sum of the numbers they wrote on the piece of paper? The final Answer is 2
 ### Proof
 The number 1 to any power is always 1, so no matter how many times Hypatia and Euclid cube their numbers, they will both always have the number 1.
 Thus, Hypatia and Euclid both write down the number 1.
 Now, lets take a look at Pythagoras. He keeps cubing his result 20 times starting with the number 2. The numbers he has are \begin{align} 2^3&\underset{\swarrow}{=}8 \\ 8^3&\underset{\swarrow}{=}512 \\
 512^3&\underset{\swarrow}{=}134217728 \\ \vdots \end{align}We can see that these numbers get out of hand pretty quickly (no wonder it took them so long), so instead, we look at the sum of the results because that is what we are trying to find.
 Recall that $(-a)^3=-a^3$. Because the number Ptolemy chose is the negation of what Pythagoras chose, after a certain number of cubes, whatever Pythagoras has, Ptolemy will have the opposite of that.
 Thus, whatever gigantic number Pythagoras has at the end of the game, Ptolemy will have the negation of that number, and they will add to zero.
 Thus, our desired sum is  \begin{align}1+1&+(\text{some huge number}) + (-\text{the same huge number})\\ &=1+1+0=\boxed{2}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes n1 n2 n3 n4 :: real
assumes h0 : "n1 = 1 ^ (3 ^ 20)"
and h1 : "n2 = 1 ^ (3 ^ 20)"
and h2 : "n3 = 2 ^ (3 ^ 20)"
and h3 : "n4 = (-2) ^ (3 ^ 20)"
shows  "n1 + n2 + n3 + n4 = 2"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Evaluate the sum of the numbers $1^{3^{20}}$, $1^{3^{20}}$, $2^{3^{20}}$, and $(-2)^{3^{20}}$. The final answer is $2$.
